title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for restrictions on securities transactions with registered investment companies, including ownership by qualified purchasers. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF QUALIFIED PURCHASER. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "Qualified purchaser" as a natural person owning at least $10,000,000 in securities, a person owning and investing at least $100,000,000 in securities, or a person determined by the Commission to not need certain protections. The Commission may determine that certain individuals, based on factors like financial sophistication, net worth, assets owned, or relationship with an issuer, do not need certain protections under the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission has the authority to establish rules and regulations for these individuals in the public interest and for investor protection. SEC. 5 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine investment securities. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph exempting companies not engaged in issuing redeemable securities, but providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to exempt companies providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state. The amendment requires that 80 percent of securities sold by the company are held by individuals in that state, sold only to accredited investors, and not invested in securities issued by investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment exempts companies providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state. Securities sold must be held by individuals in that state, sold to accredited investors, and not invested in securities issued by investment companies. Securities must be rated investment grade or meet specific investment policies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment exempts companies providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state. Companies meeting the requirements can rely on the exemption by filing a notification with the Commission. The exemption may be subject to additional terms and conditions as determined by the Commission. The exemption provided by the Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment for companies providing financial or managerial assistance for economic development in a specific state may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to change the exemption amount to $10,000,000. SEC. 8 revises the definition of eligible portfolio company by setting limits on total assets and capital. SEC. 9 updates the definition of a business development company. SEC. 9 updates the definition of a business development company by allowing exceptions for providing managerial assistance to certain types of companies as determined by the Commission. SEC. 10 amends rules for business development companies to acquire assets from various entities under Commission regulations. SEC. 11 introduces amendments related to the capital structure. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent. However, these companies may have an asset coverage of not less than 110 percent under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent, with exceptions allowing for not less than 110 percent under specific conditions. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing indebtedness without provisions to restrict dividends, distributions, or stock purchases. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing stock without provisions to restrict dividends, distributions, or stock purchases. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing stock without provisions to restrict dividends, distributions, or stock purchases. Amendments include changes to paragraph (2) and (3) regarding securities issuance by business development companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent, with exceptions allowing for not less than 110 percent under specific conditions. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to voting securities without shareholder or partner authorization and director approval. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 requires written statements to include information on portfolio and capital structure.
